Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2007 07:03PM - edited Dec 16, 2007 10:18PM by SuzCA Bimmer, I am with you in sharing your frustration that we are still losing  too many beloved people to this awful group of diseases.  Aids has lost it's almost always fatal consequences as we have been able to stop HIV from advancing.  You are right that more effort needs to be put into figuring out how to stop cancer from getting a foot hold. But for those who do have stage iv, many have benefited from an extended and good quality life through the efforts of their oncologists. Unfortunately none of the drugs currently available stopped or even slowed the type of cancer that invaded your wife's immune system.   I realize are angry and devastated that modern medicine could do so little, but please stop bashing the oncologists. They are there to try to treat the problems presented to them by whatever means available. I had to have proof sent to my Onc before he would see me. Not because he is an SOB, but because he only has enough time to deal with those who truly might be able to benefit from his help. There is no guarantee when you see any physician that they will be able to save your life. Drugs are also funded by the NIH. Drug companies do charge the highest amount that the market will bear.  For profit companies do that.  If a drug is not efficacious it does not usually make it to market in the first place which means the company bleeds money. Millions of dollars and many years of hard work are spent trying to find one that works. We consumers pay for that research when we buy something that makes it to market. If you want  be cynical,  but I can tell you that if a vaccine was discovered for cancer, all types of it, tommorow, and put on the market the day after tomorrow, no one would be put out. The drug companies would just scramble to solve Avian bird flu, obesity, diabetes, or some other ailment. Unfortunately for mankind another ailment will always be around. I don't think it's too optomistic to believe that if a cure were found that we could lift our glasses with research scientists, oncologists, their staff, cancer surgeons, radiologists and even heads of drug companies. All of us are humans, many whose loved ones have been torn from us from by this devastating disease.   That currently we have too little and too late for those we love now is unbearable. I do hope that more research is funded both by drug companies and by government.  So raise your voice, and demand more service.

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 01:15PM - edited Aug 28, 2008 01:19PM by SuzCA I did 11 rounds of assisted reproduction with hormones. I was dertermined to have a child and then give her a sibling. Some were inseminations, one of which gave me my one and only daughter.  Others were In Vitro fertilization and frozen embryo transfers.  My daughter was 3 1/2 when I was Dx'd.  It was estimated that I may have had BC as long as five years.  So I may have already had bc while I was doing all the hormones.  I had extensive DCIS, IDC in one breast and LCIS in the opposite breast.  The tumor had  low percent estrogen receptive, low enough that I don't take tamoxofin.  No PR and no HER, so I am close to triple neg, but not quite.  I too wondered though whether all those drugs had either fueled the cancer or sped up the process.  I have not found any studies though on the net that indicate that fertility drugs are linked with BC.    dx 4/8/05, dcis, idc, lcis 2.7 cm idc, stage 2, low er, pr neg, her2 neg

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2009 03:08PM SuzCA wrote: I hope you don;t mind if I chime in.  I am technically a stage II, but since my symptoms were bleeding from the nipple and there was clearly vascular invasion, I could be a III.  Who is counting.  I  am seeing my Onc this afternoon.  I would not have any other.   One of the first questions he asked dh and me was "how do you want me to spell out our findings, easy, medium or with full medical terminology?"  I appreciated that.  Each patient has a different desire to hear  or understand the details and he respected that.  The other things he did was have my blood pressure taken  before he saw me.  When the nurse noted that I had low/normal BP, she said, "good, no white coat syndrome" and wrote  -wcs on my chart.  That way the doctor knew whether he was going to be talking to someone who was scared witless or not.  After I mistakenly thought my tumor markers were going up in succession, he showed me all my numbers from the last six months to confirm they were fluctuating.  I mentioned that I probably should not know about those numbers because I had the tendency to get neurotic about them.  He never told me my numbers again.  If I ask, I am sure he will tell me.  He takes about 45 minutes with me during each of our visits.  I was down graded to every six months but then six months ago more cancer was found during a free flap surgery.  Although I don't need more tx and now sees me every three months. I trust this guy with my life, literally, so it's very important that I respect him, which I do.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2008 10:07AM SuzCA wrote: I hope your surgery goes uneventfully and you have a smooth recovery.  If you are sensitive to morphine, ie it makes you throw up, tell them they have to pre-dose you with Aloxi or Zofran IV.  That or NO Morphine.  I now put it down as something that I am allergic to so I won't get it anymore. Throwing up right after surgery is the pits.   I hope you feel a lot better once the replacement is in.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2007 02:17PM SuzCA wrote: Then she says. "Charlie, I'm not going anywhere. So don't you worry about it." Come to think about it, she's right.  She is with you.  In her mind she will always be with you. Going somewhere else isn't very interesting to her. The end (of life) means little to her. She is going to stay right by your side too.  And she will die in her own time.  There is a lot of truth in what she said.  Still, I do think that it was OK for you to give her permission to let go if she wanted. Now that she has that, she can be free to stick around until its time.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 03:58PM SuzCA wrote: I hope it's OK to jump in here for a moment.  I had 4 rounds of Abraxane preceeded by 4 rounds of Ellence.  After the first round of Abraxane,  my periods stopped.  After 9 months though they came back and i am only now going back into menopause. I was 47 when I took Abraxane, 48 when my periods returned and am now 55.  Whether your periods will return are dependant on a bunch of factors.  It was an excellent idea to harvest some eggs prior to TX.  FET's or Frozen Embryo Transfers are quite easily performed (I had a few of those, only prior to my cancer dx - it was a busy couple of years).

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2007 11:46AM SuzCA wrote:  I replied in the other post as well, but thought I'd pass this on.  I was attending bc survivor support group at my hospital shortly after I was diagnosed. Evidently some high end spas in the area would donate a spa day to cancer survivors. One of the massage therapists reportedly refused to massage a bc survivor who attended. She was convinced that this woman was contaminated. The cancer survivor was hurt, embarassed and mad as yiu could easily imagine.  People from the cancer center went out to the spa and presented an educational session with every member of each spa who participated. They probably included some sensitivity training in the process.  I hope you have a better day tomorrow.
Posts.Title: very upsetting day igutson luckywife

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 07:27PM SuzCA wrote: I am so sorry that your feelings were hurt.  I hope you can consider this perspective.  When I was going through chemo and wore scarves as my skin could no longer put up with itchy wigs, it became quite obvious that I was a cancer patient.  Drawn on eyebrows, no eyelashes and pretty frail looking.  But I still had enough energy to do the grocery shopping for my family.  I noticed that no matter which store I went to, that the teen aged clerks could not look me in the eye.  The males were the worst.  They would start a conversation with the bagger, the next checker, anybody, while they were ringing up my stuff.  I soon learned that I made these kids REALLY uncomfortable.  So I tried being friendly. No go. Rather than think they were just being heartless, I realized that dealing with someone who faces deadly illness is just not in a lot of teens ability to cope. Death is not a reality yet to them.  I am going to gather that he laughed as a gut reaction to cover his shock. he just could not deal wioth the concept that you had no hair.  It was an inappropriate response on his part, but I'll bet it shook him up to come face to face with someone he likes looking like a "real cancer patient".  Just the word "cancer" freaks some people out. You could say you have a degenerative heart condition and not get the same response as saying " I have cancer". It carries a stigma all of its own.    So you pray for that boy to grow up a little and gain perspective, and I will pray for your wounded heart.  Bless you and hugs to you. Suz

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 04:22PM - edited Dec 11, 2008 04:25PM by SuzCA I'm sorry to hear about the progression.   Even though I do not have mets (that I know of) I am mostly triple negative so I don;t do hormone therapy.  My Oncologist put me on Abraxane as my first line of tx. It caused a fair amount of neuropathy and some all over body aches.  My oncologist thinks pretty highly of it though.  The chemo sessions are  about 35-45 minutes long rather than hours.  I have also had experience with Dilaudid as I have had eight surgeries since BC dx three years ago due to reconstruction problems. The last, a TRAM flap procedure uncovered some residual cancer which we were lucky to find early.   I am allergic to morphine and never liked it much as a pain killer. Dilaudid was very nice, at least the IV version. It gave good pain control and no nausea. In pill form, I found Oxycontin to be the most effective.  I guess that is why they wanted to see what kind of port you have.  They want  to be able to give you Dilaudid and Abraxane.  I hope both give you some relief.
